item.question: Which of the following is true about the <font face="monospace">lost+found</font> directory?
item.choice: It is not mentioned in the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.
Every directory has a <font face="monospace">lost+found</font> subdirectory.
It contains unlinked files found by <font face="monospace">fsck</font>.
item.correct_answer: It is not mentioned in the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.
It contains unlinked files found by <font face="monospace">fsck</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You are looking for an executable file foo.
Select TWO commands that would search for foo within directories set in the shell variable $PATH.
item.hint: You are required to provide TWO answers. So select two, no more, no less. The question asks for an executable file, not just any file named <font face="monospace">foo</font>.

item.question:
You started the program rups in the background and you notice it consumes a lot of resources.
Which of the following commands can you use to make the command you just started use less CPU resources?
item.hint: The question is about changing the priority of a RUNNING proces. Changing the priority is done by changing the nice value of the proces. A lower value means less nice, a higher value means the proces is nicer to other processes regarding CPU resources.

item.question:
You want to know how much disk-space you are using in your homedirectory.
Which of the following commands will accomplish this?
item.hint: The question does not state what your current working directory is. Hence, the remark that you want to know the disk-space in your homedirectory allows you to easily eliminate to possible answers.

item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
Select the possible value for mode that caused the file foo to get the above permissions:
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">ls</font> has three positions to show the permissions for owner, group, and others. This means that if it needs to show the setuid permission as well as the execute permission it requires an extra position. Instead of adding an extra position <font face="monospace">ls</font> will show if both setuid and execute permissions are set or not by showing a lowercase or uppercase character <font face="monospace">s</font>. However, <font face="monospace">chmod</font> does not use <font face="monospace">ls</font> its method and requires both <font face="monospace">x</font> and <font face="monospace">s</font> if you want to set both.

item.question:

Which command can be used to find the previous runlevel?

item.question: What is the meaning of setting the sticky bit permission on a directory?
item.choice: all files created in the directory will belong to the same group as the directory.
files and directories can only be deleted by their owner
it can be used to temporarily lock the directory
files and directories can only be deleted by their owner, the owner of the directory, or a user with root privileges.
item.correct_answer: files and directories can only be deleted by their owner, the owner of the directory, or a user with root privileges.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You installed a new set of shared libraries in /usr/local/mynewlib.
You run the command ldconfig.
However, running the application still causes problems, complaining it cannot find the shared libraries.
What is most likely the cause of this?
item.choice: You forgot to enter the library path in <font face="monospace">ld.so.conf</font>.
When you install new libraries, you need to recompile or re-install the application.
You forgot to add the library path to the <font face="monospace">PATH</font> variable.
You forgot to reboot the system (the libraries are discovered at kernel initialization).
item.correct_answer: You forgot to enter the library path in <font face="monospace">ld.so.conf</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
The ________ directory is world writable.
Therefore it should be on a separate partition (filesystem) to prevent users from filling up the root-filesystem.
item.hint: Questions regarding the directory structure on Linux always assume the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard. Note that, if it is not stated explicitly your safest bet is to provide the full pathname to the directory as well.

item.question:
You need to install linux on a laptop with a 1.66 GHz processor, 2 GB of RAM and a 160 GB harddisk.
The user made clear he wants support for suspend and hibernation.
How much space on the disk would you allocate to be used as swap?
item.hint: Hibernation will write memory to the swap space. So the minimum amount of swap space required will be the amount of RAM in the system. However, this may be too limited as the system might have used some portion of the swap space to hold inactive memory pages when the physical RAM was or is full. To make sure there will be enough swap space left for hibernation a good rule of thumb is to allocate twice the amount of RAM as swap space.

item.question:

You do not know his password.

item.choice: It is not possible, because you do not know his password.
item.hint: You are root and as the root user you can become any user without providing a password.

item.question: Which condition(s) must be true if two directories each require their own quotum for filesystem usage?
item.choice: They must exist on Ext3 partitions
The directories must have the setgid permission set.
They must be on different partitions
They must be mounted by the root user
item.correct_answer: They must be on different partitions

item.hint: When it is not stated explicitly which shell is used assume the Bash shell.

item.question: Where would you add a library path if the library is currently located in your homedirectory and only temporarily used?
item.choice: Add it to the <font face="monospace">LD_LIBRARY_PATH</font> variable prior to running the command.
Add it to <font face="monospace">/etc/modprob.conf</font> and run <font face="monospace">ldconfig</font> afterwards to update the cache-file
Call the system administrator and have her add it to the correct location
item.correct_answer: Add it to the <font face="monospace">LD_LIBRARY_PATH</font> variable prior to running the command.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following commands would return all lines that contains text between brackets (i.e. [...])?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">grep</font> uses regular expression syntax to specify the match filter. Brackets allow you to specify a set of characters that may occur at a single position. The caret inside brackets means you do not want the specified characters to match at that position. The dot (<font face="monospace">.</font>) means a single random character, but within brackets means a literal dot. The backslash escapes the next character which means it loses it special meaning, if any, and will be considered literally.

item.question:
You enter a command (mycmd) in bash and want to write both standard output and standard error output correctly to a single file (mylog).
Select all correct answers.
item.hint: This is a tricky question. If you know your I/O redirection rules you will probably find one correct answer quickly. But there are actually two correct answers. Before the shell will fork and execute the command it will have rewritten the commandline and removed all special characters and words from the commandline. So the order may not be that important.

item.question: Which command can be used to show all shell-variables?
item.hint: The Bash shell treats all variables equal but some are more equal than others. The most equal variables are exported to its children and the others are not. The question is about showing ALL variables, so not only the exported ones.

item.question:
You issue the above command with root-privileges.
What will happen to your system?
item.choice: Your system will make eating sounds (yum, yum)
Your debian system will be upgraded to the new stable version
Your redhat system will be upgraded to the new release version
Packages already installed will be updated if a new version is available
item.correct_answer: Packages already installed will be updated if a new version is available
item.hint: Usually you use <font face="monospace">yum upgrade</font> to upgrade the system to a new version but this requires more actions than are mentioned in the question.

item.question:
You enabled quota support for users on the filesystem mounted on /extra.
Which file holds the current quotas for users?
item.hint: The quota system keeps its administration on the filesystem itself. Knowing that the question is about user quota support, you should be able to pick the correct answer.

item.question: What is the maximum number of primary partitions a single harddisk can contain?
item.hint: If the question requires you to type in the answer and the answer contains a number be sure to type in the number and not as text. For example if your answer is 6 type 6 and NOT six.
